The most common mobile operating systems are:
The most common mobile operating systems are:
;[[Android (operating system)|Android]] from [[Google Inc.]] <ref name="OS MS 3Q10"/> (free and open source)<ref name="ICS is coming to AOSP - Android Building">[http://groups.google.com/group/android-building/msg/c0e01b4619a1455a ICS is coming to AOSP - Android Building]</ref>
;[[Android (operating system)|Android]] from [[Google Inc.]] <ref name="OS MS 3Q10"/> (free and open source)<ref name="ICS is coming to AOSP - Android Building">[http://groups.google.com/group/android-building/msg/c0e01b4619a1455a ICS is coming to AOSP - Android Building]</ref>
  +
[[File:Galaxy Nexus smartphone.jpg|thumb|The [[Galaxy Nexus]] running Android 4.0.1]]
{{see also|Comparison of Android devices}}
{{see also|Comparison of Android devices}}
: Android was developed by a small startup company that was purchased by [[Google Inc.]], and Google continues to update the software. Android is a Linux-derived OS backed by Google, along with major hardware and software developers (such as Intel, HTC, ARM, Samsung, Motorola and eBay, to name a few), that form the [[Open Handset Alliance]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.openhandsetalliance.com/oha_members.html |title=Alliance Members |publisher=Open Handset Alliance |date= |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref> Released on November 5th 2007, the OS received praise from a number of developers upon its introduction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/146450/developers_praise_android_at_google_io.html?tk=rl_noinform |title=Developers Praise Android at Google I/O | PCWorld Business Center |publisher=PCWorld.com |date=2008-05-29 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}</ref> Android releases prior to 2.0 (1.0, 1.5, 1.6) were used exclusively on mobile phones. Most Android phones, and some Android tablets, now use a 2.x release. Android 3.0 was a tablet-oriented release and does not officially run on mobile phones. The current Android version is 4.0. Android releases are nicknamed after sweets or dessert items like Cupcake (1.5), Frozen Yogurt (2.2), Honeycomb (3.0), and Ice Cream Sandwich (4.0). Most major mobile service providers carry an Android device. Since the [[HTC Dream]] was introduced, there has been an explosion in the [[Comparison of Android devices|number of devices]] that carry Android OS. From Q2 of 2009 to the second quarter of 2010, Android's worldwide market share rose 850% from 1.8% to 17.2%. On 15 November 2011, Android reached 52.5% of the global smartphone market share.<ref>[http://econsultancy.com/uk/blog/8279-android-doubles-market-share-to-take-52-5-of-smartphone-market Android takes 52.5% of smartphone market | Econsultancy]</ref>
: Android was developed by a small startup company that was purchased by [[Google Inc.]], and Google continues to update the software. Most Android phones, and some Android tablets, now use a 2.x release. Android 3.0 was a tablet-oriented release and does not officially run on mobile phones. The current Android version is 4.0. Android releases are nicknamed after sweets or dessert items like Cupcake (1.5), Frozen Yogurt (2.2), Honeycomb (3.0), and Ice Cream Sandwich (4.0). Most major mobile service providers carry an Android device. Since the [[HTC Dream]] was introduced, there has been an explosion in the [[Comparison of Android devices|number of devices]] that carry Android OS. From Q2 of 2009 to the second quarter of 2010, Android's worldwide market share rose 850% from 1.8% to 17.2%. On 15 November 2011, Android reached 52.5% of the global smartphone market share.<ref>[http://econsultancy.com/uk/blog/8279-android-doubles-market-share-to-take-52-5-of-smartphone-market Android takes 52.5% of smartphone market | Econsultancy]</ref>
